---
title: 'Children’s cultural heritage: The micro-politics of the archive'
type: pub
encoding: UTF-8

---
<h1>Publikasjon</h1>
<article id="csl-bib-container-TWMBNTPC" class="csl-bib-container">

<div id="csl-bib-meta-TWMBNTPC" class="csl-bib-meta">
  <article id="about-article-TWMBNTPC" class="about_pub-article">
    <h1>Om</h1>
    Sparrman og Aarsand undersøker korleis barns kulturelle arv blir bevart i det svenske arkivet for barnekunst. Dei fokuserer på digitalisering og kategorisering av barneteikningar, og merkar seg at desse prosessane vanlegvis blir styrt av vaksne. Dette reiser spørsmål om korleis vaksne sine perspektiv påverkar bevaringa av barns kulturelle arv. Forfattarane argumenterer for at arkivering er ein politisk handling, då måten dokumenta blir organisert på reflekterer subjektive val. Deira analyse framhevar prosedyrene involvert i å skape ei kulturell arv for barn og vurderer korleis desse praksisane formar vår forståing av barn. Denne studien er viktig fordi den viser at bevaring av barns kulturelle arv krev nøye vurdering av korleis vaksne sine fordommar kan påverke representasjonen av barns erfaringar og identitetar.
  </article>
  <article id="keywords-article-TWMBNTPC" class="keywords-article">
    <h1>Emneord</h1>
    Barns kulturelle arv, Digitalisering, Kategorisering, Registrering, Svensk arkiv for barnekunst, Vaksne sine kategoriseringar, Politisk praksis
  </article>
  <article id="abstract-article-TWMBNTPC" class="abstract-article">
    <h1>Samandrag</h1>
    In this text, we explore the concept of children’s cultural heritage. We do so by investigating and reflecting upon the digitizing, categorizing and registering of children’s digital and analogue pictures in the Swedish Archive of Children’s Art. Children themselves do not agitate for the preservation of their own cultural heritage. As most archive taxonomies are based on adult categorizations, we ask what consequences this has for the preservation of children’s cultural heritage. From our theoretical location in Child and Heritage Studies and Science and Technology Studies, we see archived documents as infused with subjectivity by the way in which they are systematized and classified at the time of archiving. Thus, we approach the process of digitizing children’s pictures as a political practice. The micro-politics of the archive intertwines with broader politics of children and childhood as well as adult cultural heritage policies and theories. The analyses show which procedures are involved in creating a children’s cultural heritage, while also reflecting upon what notions of children become relevant for children’s cultural heritage.
  </article>
